Guided Video Capture for AI-based Assessment

This document provides the foundational understanding required for the development and integration teams to begin designing and implementing the Rural Child Development Monitoring Platform. It outlines the system objectives, the stakeholders involved, and the context in which the solution is being built. The goal is to ensure crystal-clear alignment across engineering, product, AI, and field-operations teams before development begins.

The platform aims to enable early detection of developmental delays, abnormalities, and disabilities in newborns and young children in rural India, where access to specialized pediatric and developmental experts is limited. It provides:
A structured and repeatable screening and developmental milestone assessment framework
A guided video capture system that allows mothers and workers to record standardized short clips of the child performing key developmental tasks
An AI-driven assessment engine that can analyze these videos and extract clinically relevant observations
A unified workflow for risk triage, case management, teleconsultation, and follow-up care
A scalable, offline-first system that can operate reliably in rural environments
The ultimate objective is to enable early intervention, which significantly improves long-term developmental outcomes.
Capture structured information and videos, receive guidance and follow-ups, and stay engaged in their childs developmental journey.
Conduct home visits, screening, guidance, and follow-up.
Support growth monitoring and community-based early childhood services.
Review AI-supported assessments, provide clinical impressions, advise on referrals, and guide care plans through teleconsultation.
Provide developmental observations from video, generate structured risk signals, and help address the shortage of specialists.
Automates follow-ups, risk triage, and escalations.
Why This System Is Being Built Now
Critical shortage of specialized pediatric and developmental experts in rural areas
Early developmental delays often go unnoticed until it is too late for effective intervention. A scalable system is essential to compensate for the lack of trained specialists.
Increasing acceptance of digital health and teleconsultation
Rural programs, frontline workers, and health departments are adopting digital tools, making this platform both timely and feasible.
Advances in AI for movement, posture, and behavioral analysis
Recent improvements in video-based AI models now make it possible to derive clinically meaningful signals from short, simple videoseven in low-resource settings.
Awareness that early intervention profoundly changes long-term outcomes
Identifying delays in the first 24 months dramatically improves success rates for therapy, learning, and health.
Need for structured, interoperable, FHIR-compliant data systems
As health data systems mature, there is a requirement to build solutions that can integrate with national and state digital health ecosystems.
This platform addresses these realities by combining

The Rural Child Development Monitoring Platform is a unified digital health system designed to identify developmental risks in newborns and young children early, reliably, and at scale. It integrates structured screening workflows, guided video assessments, AI-driven interpretation, community health worker inputs, and remote clinician reviewforming a continuous care loop even in low-resource, rural settings.
The platform serves three primary goals:
Early detection of developmental delays or abnormalities
through standardized screenings and AI-assisted video analysis.
via automated triage, case creation, teleconsultation, and structured care plans.
, enabling health programs to track child development trends and workforce performance.
The platform is composed of modular capabilities that together form a comprehensive early-childhood monitoring system.
Register newborns and children with demographic and clinical background.
Map each child to a village, facility, and program jurisdiction.
Age-appropriate developmental tasks and screening forms.
Structured data capture during home visits or clinic encounters.
Automated determination of relevant milestone sets based on age.
C. Guided Video Capture for AI Assessment
TikTok-style guided recording workflow for developmental tasks.
Protocol-driven instructions to ensure consistent camera angle, framing, and duration.
Offline capture and upload with built-in quality checks.
AI models analyze movement, posture, control, symmetry, and other developmental indicators.
Generate structured observations, confidence levels, and summaries.
Provide a non-diagnostic but clinically interpretable interpretation layer to augment human expertise.
Automatically open cases for medium/high risk.
Capture detected issues and triage reasoning.
Maintain a full child development health record.
Asynchronous clinician review of videos, AI outputs, and screening data.
Doctors submit Clinical Impressions and recommendations.
Ability to assign multiple clinicians or escalate to specialists.
Structured care plans and home exercises.
Follow-up visit scheduling with automated task generation.
Workflow engine ensures adherence to timelines and responsibilities.
Generates tasks for ASHAs, Anganwadi workers, caregivers, and clinicians.
Provides reminders, escalations, and expiry handling.
Ensures every case progresses through the required steps.
I. Data Interoperability via HL7 FHIR
FHIR-based representation of Patients, Encounters, Observations, Media, DiagnosticReports, CarePlans, and more.
Optional integration with ABDM, state health registries, RCH portals, or EMR/EHR systems.
Explicit consent capture for screening, video, AI, and teleconsultation.
Full audit logs, encrypted media, and privacy-by-design architecture.
The following summarizes the complete operational pipeline from enrollment to intervention:
Child is registered caregivers linked village and worker assigned.
Screening forms and milestone tasks logged.
System automatically or manually requests developmental video tasks.
Worker/mother records guided videos on mobile app.
Video uploaded analyzed by AI model.
AI outputs include developmental signals, observations, and a summary.
Combined rule-based and AI-informed triage classifies risk as Green/Amber/Red.
Clinician reviews data, interprets findings, submits Clinical Impression.
Care plan generated with specific activities.
Case resolved once clinician and program rules consider interventions adequate.
Dashboards display population trends, risks, performance, geographic patterns.
, even in remote and resource-constrained settings.
Uses guided video capture to observe developmental milestones remotely.
Machine learning models detect subtle movement, control, symmetry, and motor/cognitive indicators.
Enables early identification despite the shortage of pediatric specialists in rural areas.
B. Integrated Teleconsultation for Specialist Support
Asynchronous review reduces need for live internet connectivity.
Enables rapid expert intervention without requiring the child to travel.
Clinicians have access to structured AI outputs, videos, and screening context.
Hybrid rule-based + AI signal workflow for determining risk.
Prioritizes high-risk children for immediate action.
Minimizes false positives/negatives by combining clinical rules, video evidence, and AI interpretation.
Videos stored locally until upload possible.
Sync engine ensures reliable, conflict-free data transfer.
Screening Video AI Triage Case Teleconsult Care Plan Referral Follow-up.
End-to-end system ensures no child falls through the cracks."
Ready for national digital health integrations (ABDM, RCH).

This section defines the functional boundaries of the Rural Child Development Monitoring Platform. It outlines everything the system must supportfrom onboarding a child, to screening, AI analysis, triage, teleconsultation, and follow-up care. These functions form the backbone of the platforms MVP and future scalability.
The system must support the creation and maintenance of child profiles and their associated caregivers.
Register newborns and young children with demographic and birth details.
Link each child to one or more caregivers (mother, father, guardian).
Capture caregiver contact information, language preferences, and consent status.
Associate children with locations (village/ward) and community workers (ASHA, Anganwadi).
Maintain longitudinal records from birth through early childhood.
Support offline enrollment by frontline workers.
The platform must provide a structured mechanism for periodic developmental screening.
Provide milestone schedules based on age (e.g., 03 months, 36 months).
Present standardized screening forms and questions aligned with developmental domains.
Allow workers or caregivers to record structured observations during home visits.
Capture vitals, anthropometric measures, and key clinical indicators.
Support Questionnaire/Response workflows for data consistency.
Routine structured data that creates a reliable foundation for
Guided Video Capture for AI-based Assessment
A central component of the platform is enabling users to capture short, standardized videos of children performing specific developmental tasks.
Provide task-specific guidance (duration, framing, lighting, demonstration).
Prompt workers/mothers to capture videos based on childs developmental stage.
Validate video quality (length, visibility, angle) before upload.
Tag videos with appropriate developmental tasks and protocol versions.
Securely upload videos even over low bandwidth; support offline caching.
Maintain metadata for later AI processing and clinical review.
A consistent, structured set of videos that AI models can evaluate reliably and safely.
The platform must support automated, auditable AI analysis of videos.
Submit captured videos to an AI inference pipeline.
Track inference job status (submitted, processing, completed, failed).
Extract movement, posture, symmetry, gross motor patterns, or other developmental indicators.
Generate structured AI observations with confidence scores.
Produce a human-readable AI interpretation summary.
Maintain full lineage: model version, inference timestamp, source video, provenance.
, never final diagnoses, enabling structured triage and clinician support.
The system must convert screening inputs and AI observations into actionable clinical workflows.
Combine rule-based logic + AI signals to determine risk categories.
Generate risk assessments (green/amber/red) with supporting evidence.
Trigger alerts when abnormalities, delays, or concerns are detected.
Automatically open cases for medium/high-risk findings.
Record case events, status transitions, and resolution history.
Integrate with task workflows (follow-up visits, retake videos, escalate to doctor).
Potential developmental concerns are surfaced early and consistently through a
Where specialized expertise is unavailable locally, the system must enable remote doctor review.
Generate teleconsultation requests for flagged cases.
Allow doctors to review child data, screening results, and AI observations.
Provide synchronous or asynchronous communication between workers and doctors.
Support clinician queries, clarifications, and request for additional videos.
Capture Clinical Impressions from the reviewing specialist.
Route decisions back into case management and care plans.
Specialist input becomes accessible at scale, overcoming rural workforce shortages.
Once a clinical impression is formed, the system must support coordinated follow-up and intervention.
Generate individualized care plans with goals and recommended activities.
Assign care tasks to caregivers or workers with due dates.
Create referrals to PHCs/CHCs/District Hospitals when escalation is required.
Capture referral completion status, outcomes, and subsequent recommendations.
Track adherence to therapy or developmental exercises.
Children receive not only identification of issues but also
structured pathways to care and improvement
Given the sensitivity of pediatric health data and videos, the system must enforce robust privacy and compliance mechanisms.
Capture purpose-specific consent: screening, teleconsultation, AI processing, training data use.
Apply granular access control for roles (ASHA, clinician, admin).
Encrypt sensitive data at rest and in transit.
Maintain audit logs for all data views, edits, and AI execution events.
Ensure medically and ethically appropriate use of AI outputs.
Support compliance with health data regulations and FHIR-based interoperability.
system trusted by caregivers, clinicians, and program administrators.
Program teams need insights to manage operations and measure outcomes.
Dashboards for screening coverage, video submissions, and milestone completion.
Triage statistics (risk distribution, case counts, turnaround times).
AI accuracy monitoring (agreement between human and AI).
Export capability for research or policy reporting (with de-identification).
A data-driven decision-making environment that ensures accountability, quality, and long-term program improvement.
The platform is built as a modular, scalable system consisting of four major layers:
, while ensuring maintainability, extensibility, and compliance with health data standards.
model, with Django at the center of business logic.
Offline-first data capture, video recording, and guided workflows for workers and mothers.
Handles child enrollment, screening, case management, triage, workflows, teleconsultation, tasks, and operational rules.
HAPI FHIR Server (Interoperability & Clinical Data Layer)
Stores clinically meaningful data as structured FHIR resources (Patient, Observation, Media, DiagnosticReport, etc.).
Securely processes videos, generates structured observations, and provides explainable summaries.
Django communicates with HAPI FHIR using RESTful FHIR APIs.
Mobile communicates only with Django, not directly with FHIR or AI servers.
AI inference is triggered via Django, and results are synchronized back into both Django and FHIR.
Domain Model (Django as System of Record)
Manage child identities, caregivers, and relationships
Store encounters, screening responses, tasks, and case management events
Store video metadata before and after AI inference
Manage teleconsult workflows and doctor interactions
Maintain configuration, rules, milestones, and developmental tasks
Handle authentication, authorization, and program-level permissions
Drive all notifications, reminders, and follow-up logic
Manage offline sync logic and conflict resolution
, storing all medically relevant data in standardized FHIR formats.
Store all clinical data as FHIR resources (Patient, Encounter, Observation, Media)
Provide FHIR-compliant historical lineage and versioning
Enable interoperability with external programs, governments, and partners
Provide structured, machine-readable clinical records for reporting and longitudinal analysis
Maintain provenance data for AI model usage and clinical decision support
Django references stored fhir_id for synchronization
The result is a clean, standards-based clinical record system without burdening Django with FHIR semantics.
The AI layer processes developmental videos to generate structured, explainable observations.
User captures video in mobile app.
Django stores metadata and uploads media to object storage.
Django triggers AI inference job (synchronous or asynchronous).
AI model processes video (pose estimation, motion analysis, developmental pattern extraction).
Django stores results and optionally pushes mapped FHIR resources to HAPI (Observation, DiagnosticReport, Provenance).
Full traceability is maintained (model version, run ID, timestamps).
Architecture supports multiple models evolving over time.
Computation can run on cloud GPU or edge node based on deployment.
AI never closes a case or approves/disapproves a diagnosis.
Human review is always mandatory for medium/high-risk cases.
All AI-generated content is explainable and auditable.
Local encrypted storage for child data, visits, and forms
Queued sync mechanism using FHIR-like Bundles or JSON APIs
Video compression and offline caching before upload
Ability to conduct full screening offline, including questionnaire responses and vitals
Sync triggered automatically when connectivity returns
Present guided workflows to ASHA/Anganwadi workers
Capture structured data for each encounter
Display AI or clinician feedback (once synced)
A seamless user experience even in
, ensuring no data loss and complete child histories.
This section describes the core data entities that form the backbone of the platform. The domain model is designed using
, where each functional area of the system is modeled as an explicit domain with well-defined boundaries and responsibilities.
The goal is to ensure clarity, maintainability, testability, and long-term extensibility.
This domain model acts as the
, while FHIR resources act as the
AI interpretation outputs (stored in Django, mirrored to FHIR where relevant)
Independent evolution of domains (screening, AI, triage, teleconsult)
Strong alignment between business logic and database structure
Each domain entity captures real-world concepts (child, caregiver, encounter, video, AI output, case, referral) while remaining decoupled from the FHIR resource structure.
Below is a structured explanation of each major entity group in the Django domain model.
These entities define who the system is managing and interacting with.
Represents the newborn / young child tracked by the system.
Contains demographic details, birth information, and identifiers.
Stores contact information and language preferences.
Defines relationships between child and caregivers.
Supports one-to-many mappings (one mother many children).
Represents system users such as ASHA, Anganwadi workers, doctors, and admins.
Defines user roles for access control and workflow permissions.
Represents the geographic and service point hierarchy.
To maintain a clean separation between
These entities record all interactions and clinical findings.
Represents a screening visit, home visit, or clinic visit.
Links to child, worker, and timestamp.
Represents structured measurements and screening values.
Used for vitals, growth metrics, and specific clinical indicators.
To maintain a longitudinal clinical record of each visit and observation.
These entities support milestone-based assessments and structured screening tools.
Represents specific developmental tasks (e.g., rolling over, head control).
Defines instructions for capturing task-specific videos.
Defines and records structured questionnaires for routine visits.
, structured milestone assessments, and consistent data capture.
These entities manage videos/images uploaded for AI analysis and clinical review.
Wraps MediaAsset and adds child-specific metadata.
Links video to the developmental task and protocol version.
Represents system-generated prompts asking for a particular developmental video.
, why it was captured, and how it is processed.
These entities represent AI-driven analysis of developmental videos.
Versioned model definition (architecture, version, training details).
Execution instance of an AI model processing a video.
Structured output from AI (movement patterns, symmetry scores, etc.).
Human-readable synthesized interpretation of multiple AI signals.
High-level classification derived from AI (e.g., possible motor delay risk).
These entities drive early detection and clinical risk management.
Evaluates risk categories (green/amber/red) using rules + AI signals.
Specific concerns identified during triage (e.g., delayed milestone).
For prominent warnings to highlight children needing urgent review.
To continuously evaluate the childs developmental trajectory and surface risks early.
These entities handle escalation, remote clinician review, and case resolution.
Represents a clinically significant concern that needs review or intervention.
Opened automatically (by risk rules or AI) or manually by workers/doctors.
Timeline of updates, notes, and state transitions.
Represents the structured interaction with remote clinicians.
The specialists final assessment and notes.
that supports remote review and consistent clinical governance.
These entities define the action plan for children identified as at-risk.
The childs intervention plan linked to a case.
Individual tasks or therapies inside the plan.
Represents a referral to a health facility.
Captures what happened when the child visited the facility.
To ensure that risks lead to
These entities drive operational workflows across the system.
Assignments for workers, caregivers, or clinicians.
To operationalize workflows such as re-capturing videos, screening follow-ups, or referral visits.
These entities ensure compliance with ethical and regulatory requirements.
Purpose-specific consent for screening, teleconsultation, AI processing.
Captures every significant system action (data access, modifications, AI runs).
Stored in HAPI FHIR for clinical data lineage.
, especially around pediatric media and AI.

The AI component of the platform enables scalable early detection of developmental delays by analyzing short, guided videos recorded by caregivers or frontline workers. This section defines the requirements for safe, explainable, and clinically aligned AI operation.
The AI system is designed to
, not replace, clinical assessment by providing automated observations from video. Its core purposes are:
, and other indicators relevant to developmental milestones.
from videos captured under varied rural conditions.
that help frontline workers and clinicians prioritize children who may need early intervention.
To compensate for shortages of pediatric specialists by enabling
To support longitudinal tracking by providing standardized metrics over time.
It generates observations and risk hints that feed into the triage and teleconsultation workflows.
AI performance depends heavily on video quality and capture consistency.
The platform must enforce standardized capture protocols for each developmental task.
Each developmental task has a defined protocol (duration, posture, activity).
The mobile app must display clear instructions before recording.
Frame the entire child (or relevant body parts) as per task guidelines.
Ensure adequate lighting and minimal background movement.
Avoid obstructions, including blankets, pillows, or other objects.
Basic visibility (e.g., child present in frame)
Prompt user to retake if quality is insufficient.
Videos may be recorded offline and uploaded later.
Temporary encrypted storage must be used during offline capture.
Videos become standardized enough to support high-quality AI analysis while remaining easy for rural caregivers and workers to capture.
AI Inference Output Requirements (Observations, Confidence, Report)
, ensuring both machine-readability and human interpretability.
AI must produce structured outputs that map directly to Django entities (AIObservation) and optionally to FHIR Observation. Examples:
Every observation must include a numeric confidence (0100 or 01).
Low-confidence observations may be suppressed or marked for human review.
A single human-readable summary of the video, including:
This becomes the input for clinicians reviewing teleconsultation cases.
AI may generate a preliminary risk hint (low/medium/high) with justification.
This feeds triage logic but cannot independently trigger a diagnosis.
AI outputs must always pass through
before being used in clinical decision-making.
Clinicians validate flagged cases during teleconsultation.
Multiple AI observations disagree or contradict developmental expectations
The video quality is poor but AI still produced output
Provide step-by-step instructions for better capture
Mark cases for follow-up even if AI shows no concerns
AI outputs must be auditable, traceable, and reproducible.
Every inference must reference the model version used.
Video files stored in encrypted object storage
AI outputs stored in the Django DB as structured JSON + linked tables
FHIR representations (Media, Observation, DiagnosticReport, Provenance) stored in HAPI FHIR
Videos retained according to program policy
Provenance data non-deletable except under strict compliance rules
AI cannot overwrite previous outputsonly append new inference records
Deprecated models must not be used for new analyses
All AI outputs must be explainable or accompanied by limitations
The platform uses Django as the
represents all clinically significant information using standardized HL7 FHIR R4 resources.
All synchronization between Django and FHIR must follow best practices around:
Proper use of clinical semantics (Observation, DiagnosticReport, Condition, Encounter, etc.)
Standards-compliant coding systems (SNOMED, LOINC, ICD, UCUM)
The purpose of this mapping is to ensure that:
AI outputs and clinical decisions are
The system is future-proof and EHR-compatible
Django pushes/updates FHIR resources when certain events occur.
FHIR IDs are stored in Django to maintain referential stability.
All clinical or clinically relevant events produce a
Only validated clinical data is pushed to FHIR; operational noise stays in Django.
Facility as Organization, site as Location
for creating and updating clinical data in the HAPI server.
Bundles ensure atomicity, reduce round-trips, and support offline sync.
Used when a worker completes a routine screening.
Observations (weight, length, head circumference, clinical notes)
B. Video Capture + AI Interpretation Bundle
Used after AI completes processing on a video.
Triggered when triage indicates medium/high risk.
To ensure strict, standards-based interoperability, the platform must define FHIR
These profiles ensure clinical meaning and prevent inconsistent or ambiguous data capture.
The following must be used wherever applicable:

The platform exposes a layered set of APIs to ensure clean separation of concerns, scalability, and interoperability. All APIs must be versioned, secure, and designed for low-bandwidth rural environments while maintaining alignment with FHIR semantics.
Architecture includes three major API layers:
Internal System APIs (Workflow, AI, Case Management)
Each API plays a specific role and must follow consistent principles around authentication, idempotency, validation, and error handling.
with the Django backend (never directly with FHIR or AI inference services).
Contracts must be stable, lightweight, and optimized for offline-first behavior.
Role-based access control (ASHA, Anganwadi, mother, clinician)
Fetch assigned children by worker or region
Sync pending videos when connectivity returns
E. AI Result Delivery to Mobile
Mobile does not call the AI service directly
Django pushes AI evaluation results to mobile via:
Fetch tasks assigned to a worker
Submit task outcomes (review, retake video, follow-up visit)
Response bodies must be compressed where possible
Filtering by time, region, and child
Internal Service APIs (Workflow, AI, Case Management)
These APIs expose internal functionalities that are not accessible to mobile clients. They organize backend services into clean modules with clear contracts.
Trigger tasks (video request, follow-up visit, teleconsult request)
Endpoint to submit a video for inference:
Input: video ID, task ID, protocol metadata
Endpoint to receive AI results (webhook or pull)
Endpoint to validate model version, health, and availability
Open/close cases based on triage logic
Link AI outputs and clinical impressions
Manage state transitions (open under review closed)
The FHIR Gateway handles all outbound and inbound interactions with the HAPI FHIR server.
This must be isolated from mobile and operational APIs.
Submit AI outputs as DiagnosticReport + Observation
Updates from facility systems (e.g., referral outcomes)
Federated identity or external patient updates
Proper use of HTTP verbs: GET, POST, PUT, PATCH
Store fhir_id, ETag, and version info
Translate Django entities to FHIR resources
Handle retry logic and error propagation
To ensure reliabilityespecially under intermittent connectivityAPIs must enforce strict error-handling and idempotency rules.
Include actionable messages for mobile users ("Retake video", "Retry upload")
Bundle transactions must fail entirely or succeed entirely
Mobile sync should report item-level status
Every create/update request must support an
Offline submissions must not create duplicates
Video upload session IDs must be reusable
AI inference triggers must be idempotent to avoid double processing
Case creation must use conditional logic (open case if not existing)
Mobile retries must not create duplicates
Correlation ID for FHIR and AI events
This ensures complete traceability for debugging and clinical safety audits.

The workflow engine is the backbone of the platforms operational automation. It ensures that every significant eventscreening, video capture, AI output, risk assessment, case opening, teleconsultation, and referraltriggers predictable, auditable, and actionable tasks for the right users.
workflow engine that can operate reliably in low-connectivity environments and scale to thousands of workers and children.
Every operational action in the platform is represented as a
Tasks are assigned to users or roles (ASHA, Anganwadi worker, clinician) and progress through a well-defined lifecycle.
Newly created; not yet viewed or accepted.
User has acknowledged and started working on it.
User has performed the required action (screening, video upload, follow-up).
User could not complete the action (child unavailable, bad video quality, etc.).
Deadline passed without action; requires escalation.
Each transition must be timestamped and logged in the
The workflow engine must support multiple task types, including but not limited to:
Capture video for a given developmental task/protocol.
Automatically generated when AI signals poor quality or insufficient data.
Triggered by triage or clinician recommendation.
Assigned to doctors to review AI outputs and child data.
Workers or caregivers must complete a hospital visit.
Home exercises, facility visits, therapy sessions.
defining when it should be created
Assignment logic must be configurable and override-friendly.
A child enters a new milestone stage
A video is requested for AI assessment
This event-driven model ensures the system is proactive, not reactive.
Escalations ensure no child falls through the cracks by enforcing timely action.
Tasks with deadlines must support time-based escalations such as:
High-risk cases not reviewed by clinicians
High-risk classifications from triage or AI require urgent escalation:
These tiers drive escalation response rules.
If AI or clinician identifies poor video quality:
Link the new video to the same assessment request
Escalation routing must be configurable per deployment.
The workflow engine must seamlessly integrate with teleconsultation workflows and time-based scheduling.
When a child is flagged for review:
, which drive push notifications and offline reminders.
All workflows must be traceable in the
All tasks must ultimately resolve into:
This ensures each childs pathway is

The platform deals with highly sensitive pediatric health dataincluding videos of infantsand integrates AI-driven evaluations. This requires adherence to strict security, consent, and compliance frameworks to maintain trust, ensure ethical operation, and meet regulatory expectations.
The system must follow principles of
The platform must enforce a multi-layered security model protecting every endpoint and data flow.
Support secure session renewal and token expiration.
Mobile devices must securely store tokens using OS-provided secure storage.
Include device-binding checks for frontline workers when possible.
Access to childrens data must depend on:
Clinicians see only cases assigned to them.
Workers see only children under their geographic/program jurisdiction.
Caregivers see only their own children.
AI services have no direct read access to clinical data; input is pushed via secure job submission.
Prevent simultaneous logins from multiple devices (optional but recommended).
Optional PIN/biometric authentication within the app.
Consent must be explicit, purpose-bound, and traceable. The system must follow the principle:
No action without consent, no reuse beyond purpose.
Use of anonymized data for training or quality improvement (optional)
Linked to the caregiver who provided it
Stored both in Django (operational) and in FHIR (as Consent resources)
Provided digitally or via assisted capture by frontline workers.
Stored offline until sync is possible.
Must include language-specific explanations for caregivers.
Users must be able to revoke consent for future actions.
Revocation does not retroactively erase past clinical records, but disables future AI/video use.
System must block actions requiring consent until consent is present.
AI inference must check consent flags before running.
Teleconsult workflow must verify teleconsult consent.
Handling pediatric video and health data requires enterprise-grade protection.
All videos, images, and media assets encrypted using strong encryption (AES-256).
Database encryption for sensitive fields (PII, health data).
Secrets managed using a secure secrets manager (Vault/KMS).
Set retention periods for videos and AI logs based on program policy.
Anonymization or deletion must be supported for obsolete or expired data.
Every access to sensitive data must generate an AuditLog entry with:
For FHIR resources, AuditEvent must mirror this behavior.
Pre-signed URLs with short expiry for media downloads
No direct storage access from mobile or AI services
Local device data must be encrypted.
Videos stored offline must auto-delete after successful upload.
Workers must not have access to decrypted raw files outside the app.
AI is being used to augment human assessment; therefore, strict clinical guardrails are required.
mark a child as healthy or normal without clinician confirmation.
AI must not bypass consent checks.
Limitations (e.g., "low confidence due to poor lighting")
AI flags moderate or high risk
Video quality is poor, but AI still produced output
Every deployed model must be registered in AIModel.
Every inference must store full provenance:
Deprecated models must be blocked from new evaluations.
If the AI pipeline fails or is unavailable:
System must notify worker to retry
No clinical workflow should break or halt
Track AI-human agreement levels over time
Log false positives/negatives (as identified by clinicians)
No re-use of data for training unless explicitly consented
Transparent communication to caregivers about AI usage
The platform requires a secure, scalable, and maintainable deployment architecture.

Because the system handles sensitive pediatric health data, including videos and AI outputs, DevOps practices must ensure reliability, confidentiality, traceability, and compliance across all environments.
The deployment approach is split into multiple environments, with CI/CD pipelines managing safe promotion of builds and infrastructure supporting logging, monitoring and health stabilization.
, each with clear boundaries, data separation, and access policies.
Local database with seed sample data
Mock/stub services for AI and FHIR
API contract testing for mobile and backend
Ability to simulate low bandwidth mobile sync
Live system used by frontline workers, caregivers, and clinicians
Real FHIR HAPI server with versioning and backups
Auto-scaling for backend and inference loads
The HAPI FHIR server is the
and must be deployed for reliability, scalability, and compliance.
Reverse proxy (NGINX/Envoy) in front for rate limiting & TLS termination
Daily full backups + hourly incremental backups
Strict access policies (backend only; no public access)
Mutual TLS between Django and FHIR optional
FHIR audit logging (AuditEvent) must be enabled
FHIR resources must maintain historical versions (_history)
Deploy schema migrations in controlled phases
The CI/CD pipeline must enforce quality, safety, and compliance while enabling rapid iteration.
Unit tests for Django and mobile
Container image builds (Django, AI service, FHIR gateway)
Automated version tagging and artifact management
App versioning aligned with backend capabilities
The system must have full observability across all major components: Django backend, mobile API, AI inference engine, FHIR server, and object storage.
Centralized log aggregation (ELK, Cloud Logging, etc.)
Use Prometheus/Grafana or equivalent for observability.
AI inference queue depth & processing times
Excessive delay in teleconsult response times
These logs form part of the compliance posture and must be tamper-proof.

This section outlines the phased delivery plan for the Rural Child Development Monitoring Platform. The goal is to ensure a predictable build-out of capabilities, starting with a functional and safe MVP, followed by AI enhancements, analytics, and full-scale national readiness.
Enable scale across states and programs
Basic demographics, identifiers, and location mapping
Developmental tasks and structured milestone capture
Guided video capture for selected developmental tasks
Basic inference pipeline with stub or limited-model capability
No clinical risk scoring yet (triage via simple rules)
Green / Amber / Red classification via rules
Case creation, status updates, and timeline events
Basic DiagnosticReport mapping for AI output
A functional pilot-ready system that enables real child screening and limited AI-assisted assessments, validated by frontline workers and clinicians.
Combined scoring informed by observations, history, and AI outputs
Refine FHIR profiles and implement validation layer
A clinically robust, AI-enabled platform with analytics, pipelines, and governance structures to support multi-district deployments.
, with enterprise-grade integrations, scalability, and compliance.
Horizontal scaling of Django, AI & FHIR services
Cognitive, social, and fine motor developmental indicators
A fully scalable, clinically compliant, AI-augmented platform capable of supporting
, integrated into national digital health infrastructure and rural health workflows.
This appendix provides a consolidated view of the platforms core data entities and their relationships. The ER Model reflects the
and is structured into functional domains: Identity, Encounters, Screening, Media, AI Processing, Triage, Case Management, Teleconsultation, Care Plans, Workflow, Consent, and Audit.
The purpose of this ER Model is to:
Provide developers and SI partners with a reference blueprint
Serve as the canonical guide for database schema design and migrations
Ensure alignment between backend development, API design, AI integration, and FHIR mappings
Maintain data integrity and enforce strong relational boundaries
model system users such as ASHA workers, clinicians, and supervisors.
captures a visit or screening event.
records structured measurements, vitals, or clinical findings.
links media to developmental tasks and children.
represents actionable items for users (screening, video upload, follow-up).
